titleStmt.title: Historical collections of the church in Ireland during the reigns of K. Henry VIII, Edward VI and Q. Mary wherein are several material passages omitted by other historians concerning the manner how that kingdom was first converted to the Protestant religion and how by the special providence of God, Dr. Cole, a bloody agent of Q. Mary was prevented in his designs against the Protestants there : set forth in the life and death of George Browne, sometime Archbishop of Dublin, who was the first of the Romish clergy in Ireland that threw off the Popes supremacy and forsook the idolatrous worship of of [sic] Rome : with a sermon of his on that subject.
titleStmt.author: Ware, Robert, d. 1696.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 51 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 11 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

Mary was prevented in his designs against the Protestants there : set forth in the life and death of George Browne, sometime Archbishop of Dublin, who was the first of the Romish clergy in Ireland that threw off the Popes supremacy and forsook the idolatrous worship of of [sic] Rome : with a sermon of his on that subject.

Browne, George, d. 1556.

Caption title: The reformation of the Church of Ireland in the life and death of George Browne, sometime Archbishop of Dublin, &c.
Reproduction of original in Duke University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Hi≈øtorical Collections OF THE CHURCH IN IRELAND, DURING The Reigns of K. Henry, VIII.
Edward, VI. and Q. Mary:

WHEREIN Are ≈øeveral material Pa≈ø≈øages (omitted by other Hi≈øtorians) concerning the Manner how that Kingdom was fir≈øt converted to the Prote≈øtant Religion; and how by the ≈øpecial Providence of God, Dr. Cole, a bloody Agent of Q. Mary, was prevented in his De≈øigns again≈øt the Prote≈øtants there:

Set forth in the Life and Death of GEORGE BROWNE, ≈øometime Arcbi≈øhop of Dublin, who was the fir≈øt of the Romi≈øh Clergy in Ireland that threw off the Popes Supremacy, and for≈øook the Idolatrous Wor≈øhip of of Rome; with a Sermon of his on that Subject.
Printed at London, and ≈øold by Randal Tayler, 1681.

div.head: The Reformation of the Church of Ireland, in the Life and Death of GEORGE BROWNE, ≈øometime Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, &c.
div.p: GEORGE BROWNE, by Birth an Engli≈øhman, of the Order of St. Augu≈øtine in London, and Provincial of the Fryars of the ≈øame Order in England, being a Man of a meek and peaceable Spirit, was preferr'd to the Archiepi≈øcopal See of Dublin by King Henry the Eighth, and con≈øecrated before his Arrival into Ireland, by Thomas Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, two other Bi≈øhops a≈ø≈øi≈øting him, viz. John then Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter and Nicholas then Bi≈øhop of Sarubury, on the 19th of March, Anno 1535.

The Reverend James ∆≤≈øher late Primate of Armagh, among≈øt his Memorials of Ireland, gives this holy Father this De≈øcription; George Browne was a Man of a cheerful Countenance, in his Acts and Deeds plain down right, to the poor merciful and compa≈ø≈øionate, pitying the ≈øtate and condition of the Souls of the People, advi≈øing them, when he was Provincial of the Augu≈øtine Order in England, to make their applications ≈øoly to Chri≈øt, which Advice coming to the Ears of Henry the 8th he became a Favourite, and upon the decea≈øe of John Allen late Archbi≈øhop of Dublin became his Succe≈ø≈øor; within five years after that he had enjoyed that See, he (much about the time that King Henry the 8th began to demoli≈øh the Priories, Abbeys and Mona≈øteries formerly Built by the Romi≈øh Clergy within the≈øe His Maje≈øties Dominions of England and Ireland) cau≈øed all Super≈øtitious Reliques and Images to be removed out of the two Cathedrals in Dublin, and out of the re≈øt of the Churches within his Dioce≈øs; he cau≈øed the Ten Commandements, the Lords Prayer and the Creed to be placed, being gilded and in Frames, about the Altar in the Cathedral of Chri≈øt-Church in Dublin; he was the fir≈øt that turned from the Romi≈øh Religion of the Clergy here in Ireland, to embrace the Reformation of the Church of England; for which Fact he was by Queen Mary laid a≈øide, and his Temporality taken from him, yet he patiently endured Affliction for the Truth to the end.

Upon the Reformation of King Henry 8th in England, and at his Renouncing the Papal Power or Supremacy of Rome, the Lord Thomas Cromwell then Lord Privy Seal wrote unto George Browne then Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, ≈øignifying from his Highne≈øs (then terming the King by that Title) that he was fallen ab≈øolutely from Rome in Spiritual matters within his Dominion of England, and how it was his Royal Will and Plea≈øure to have his Subjects there in Ireland to obey his Commands as in England, nominating the ≈øaid George Browne Archbi≈øhop one of his Commi≈ø≈øioners for the Execution thereof, who in a ≈øhort ≈øpace of time wrote to the Lord Privy Seal, as followes:

body.p: YOur humble Servant receiving your Mandate, as one of His Highne≈øs's Commi≈ø≈øioners, hath endeavoured almo≈øt to the danger George Cromer then Arch bi≈øhop of Armagh. and hazard of this temporal life, to procure the Nobility and Gentry of this Nation to due obedience, in owning of his Highne≈øs their ≈øupream Head as well Spiritual as Temporal, and do find much oppugning therein, e≈øpecially by my Brother Armagh, who hath been the main oppugner; and ≈øo hath withdrawn mo≈øt of his Suffragans and Clergy within his See and Juri≈ødiction, he made a Speech to them, laying a Cur≈øe on the people who≈øoever ≈øhould own his Highne≈øs Supremacy; ≈øaying, that I≈øle, as it is in their Iri≈øh Chronicles, In≈øula ≈øacra, belongs to none but to the Bi≈øhop of Rome, and that it was the Bi≈øhop of Romes Predece≈ø≈øors gave it to the Kings Ancestors. There be two Me≈ø≈øengers by the Prie≈øts of Armagh, and by that Archbi≈øhop, now lately ≈øent to the Bi≈øhop of Rome. Your Lord≈øhip may inform his Highne≈øs, that it is convenient to call a Parliament in this Nation, to pa≈øs the Supremacy by Act; for they do not much matter his Highne≈øs's Commi≈ø≈øion which your Lord≈øhip ≈øent us over. This I≈øland hath been for a long time held in Ignorance by the Romi≈øh Orders; and as for their Secular Orders, they be in a manner as ignorant as the people, being not able to ≈øay ma≈øs, or pronounce the Words, they not knowing what they them≈øelves ≈øay in the Roman Tongue: the Common people of this I≈øle are more zealous in their Blindne≈øs than the Saints and Martyrs were in Truth at the beginning of the Go≈øpel. I ≈øend to you my very good Lord the≈øe things, that your Lord≈øhip and his Highne≈øs may con≈øult what is to be done. It is feared O Neal will be ordered by the Bi≈øhop of Rome to oppo≈øe your Lord≈øhips Order from the Kings Highne≈øs; for the Natives are much in Numbers within his Powers. I do pray the Lord Chri≈øt to defend your Lord≈øhip from your Enemies.

div.p: The Year following a Parliament was called in Ireland, the Lord Leonard Grey being then King Henry's Vice-Roy of that Nation, in which George Browne, then being not many Months above a Year in his Archipi≈øcopal Chair in Dublin, ≈øtood up and made this ≈øhort Speech following:

div.head: My Lords and Gentry of this His Maje≈øties Realm of Ireland.
div.p: BEhold, your Obedience to your King is the Ob≈øerving of your God and Saviour Chri≈øt; for He, that High Prie≈øt of our Souls, paid Tribute to Ce≈øar (though no Chri≈øtian) greater Honour then ≈øurely is due to your Prince His Highne≈øs the King, and a Chri≈øtian one; Rome and her Bi≈øhops in the Fathers days acknowledged Emperors, Kings and Princes to be Supream over their Dominions, nay Chri≈øts own Vi ‚Ä¢ ans; And it is as much to the Bi≈øhop of Romes ≈øhame, te deny what their precedent Bi≈øhops owned; therefore his Highne≈øs claims but what he can ju≈øtifie the Bi≈øhop Elutherius gave to St. Lucius the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of the Britains; ≈øo that I ≈øhall without ≈øcrupling vote his Highne≈øs King Henry my Supream over Eccle≈øia≈øtick matters as well as Temporal, and Head thereof, even of both I≈øles England and Ireland, and that without Guilt of Con≈øcience or ≈øin to God; and he who will not pa≈øs this Act, as I do, is no true Subject to His Highne≈øs.

This Speech of George Browne ≈øtartled the other Bi≈øhops and Lords ≈øo, that at la≈øt through great difficulty it pa≈ø≈øed, upon which Speech Ju≈øtice Brabazon ≈øeconded him, as appears by his Letter to the Lord Thomas Cromwell then Lord Privy Seal of England, which original is in that famous Library of Sir Robert Cotton, out of which Sir James Ware, that learned Antiquary, tan≈øcribed the ≈øame.

Within few years after that the Act of Supremacy had pa≈øt in Ireland we do find a Letter written by George Browne to the Lord Cromwell, complaining of the Clergy how they fell off from what had pa≈øt, and how the Bi≈øhop of Rome had contrived matters again≈øt the then Reformation: Collected by Sir James Ware, out of an old Regi≈øtry ≈øome time in the cu≈øtody of Adam Loftus, Hugh Corwins Succe≈ø≈øor, and al≈øo Archbi≈øhop of Dublin.

body.head: Right Honourable and my ≈øingular good Lord.
body.p:
I Acknowledge my bounden Duty to your Lord≈øhips Good will to me, next to my Saviour Chri≈øts, for the Place I now po≈ø≈øe≈øs; I pray God give me his Grace to execute the ≈øame to his G lory and his Highne≈øs's Honour, with your Lord≈øhips In≈øtructions The People of this Nation be zealous, yet blind and unknowing; mo≈øt of the (lergy, as your Lord≈øhip hath had from me before, being ignorant, and not able to ≈øpeak right Words in the Ma≈øs or Liturgy, as being
not skilled in the Latin Grammar; ≈øo that a Bird may be taught to ≈øpeak with as much ≈øen≈øe as ≈øeveral of them do in this Country. The≈øe ≈øorts, though not Scholars, yet are crafty to cozen the poor Common People, and to di≈ø≈øuade them from following his Highne≈øs's Orders: George my Brother of Armagh doth underhand occa≈øion Quarrels, and is not active to execute his Highne≈øs's Orders in his Dioce≈øs.

I have ob≈øerved your Lord≈øhips Letter of Commi≈ø≈øion, and do find ≈øeveral of my Pupils leave me for ≈øo doing. I will not put others in their Livings till I do know your Lord≈øhips Plea≈øure; for it is meet I acquaint you fir≈øt, the Romi≈øh Reliques and Images of both my Cathedrals in Dublin, of the Holy Trinity and of St. Patricks, took off the Common People from the true Wor≈øhip, but the Prior and the Dean find them ≈øo ≈øweet for their Gain, that they heed not my Words: Therefore ≈øend in your Lord≈øhips next to me an Order more full, and a Chide to them and their Canons, that they might be removed. Let the Order be, that the Chief Governours may a≈ø≈øi≈øt me in it. The Prior and Dean have written to Rome, to be encouraged, and if it be not hindred before they have a Mandate from the Bi≈øhop of Rome, the People will be bold, and then tugg long before his Highne≈øs can ≈øubmit them to his Graces Orders. The Country Folk here much hate your Lord≈øhip, and de≈øpitefully call you in their Iri≈øh Tongue the Black≈ømiths Son.

The Duke of Norfolk is by Armagh, and that Clergy, de≈øired to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, not to ≈øuffer his Highne≈øs to alter Church Rules here in Ireland: As a Friend I de≈øire your Lord≈øhip to look to your Noble Per≈øon; for Rome hath a great kindne≈øs for that Duke (for it is ≈øo talked here) and will reward him and his Children. Rome hath great Favours for this Nation, purpo≈øely to oppo≈øe His Highne≈øs; and ≈øo having got, ≈øince the Act pa≈ø≈øed, great Indulgences for Rebellion, therefore my hope is lo≈øt, yet my Zeal is to do according to your Lord≈øhips Orders. God keep your Lord≈øhip from your Enemies here and in England.
body.closer:
Dublin the 3d. Kalends April. 1538.
Your Lord≈øhips at Commandement, George Browne To the Lord Privy Seal his Honourable good Lora≈øhips Ex Autographo.

div.p: Soon after this Letter had been written, News came to the Ca≈øtle of Dublin, that the Bi≈øhop of Rome had ≈øent over a Bull of Excomunication of all tho≈øe who had or ≈øhall own the Kings Supremacy within the Iri≈øh Nations; whichcau≈øed the Archbi≈øhop to write accordingly.

body.p: MY Duty premi≈øed, it may plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip to be adverti≈øed, ≈øithence my la≈øt there has come to Armagh and his Clergy a private Commi≈ø≈øion from the Bi≈øhop of Rome, prohibiting His Gratious Highne≈øs's people here in this Nation to own his Royal Supremacy, and joyning a Cur≈øe to all them and theirs who ≈øhall not within forty days, confe≈øs to their Confe≈ø≈øors, (after the publi≈øhing of it to them) that they have done ami≈øs in ≈øo doing: the ≈øub≈øtance, as our Secretary hath tran≈ølated the ≈øame into Engli≈øh, is thus.

q.p: I A B. from this pre≈øent hour forward in the pre≈øence of the holy Trinity, of the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mother of God, of St. Peter, of the holy Apo≈øtles, Archangels, Angels, Saints and of all the holy Ho≈øt of Heaven, ≈øhall and will beThe form of their Confe≈ø≈øion to their Popi≈øh Prie≈øt. always obedient to the holy See of St. Peter of Rome, and to my holy Lord the Pope of Rome and his Succe≈ø≈øors, in all things as well ≈øpiritual as temporal, not con≈øenting in the lea≈øt that his holine≈øs ≈øhall lo≈øe the lea≈øt Title or Dignity belonging to the Papacy of our Mother Church of Rome, or to the Regality of St. Peter.
I do vow and ≈øwear to maintain, help and a≈ø≈øi≈øt the ju≈øt Laws, Liberties and Rights of the Mother Church of Rome.

I do likewi≈øe promi≈øe to confer, to defend and promote, if not per≈øonally, yet willingly, as in ability able, either by Advice, Skill, E≈øtate, Mony or otherwi≈øe, the Church of Rome and her Laws again≈øt all what≈øoever re≈øi≈øting the ≈øame.

I further how to oppugn all Hereticks, either in making or ≈øetting forth Edicts or Commands contrary to the Mother Church of Rome, and in ca≈øe any ≈øuch to be moved or compo≈øed, to re≈øi≈øt it to the uttermo≈øt of my power, with the fir≈øt convenience and opportunity I can po≈ø≈øible.
I count and value all Acts made or to be made by Heretical Powers of no force or worth, or be practi≈øed or obeyed by my ≈øelf, or by any other Son of the Mother Church of Rome.

I do further declare him or her, Father or Mother, Brother or Si≈øter, Son or Daughter, Hu≈øband or Wife, Vncle or Aunt, Nephew or Neece, Kin≈øman or Kin≈øwoman Ma≈øter or Mi≈øtre≈øs, and all others, neare≈øt or deare≈øt Relations, Friend or Acquaintance what≈øoever, accur≈øed, that either do or ≈øhall hold for the time to come, any Eccle≈ø≈øa≈øtical or Civil, power above the Authority of the Mother Church, or that do or ≈øhall obey, for the time to come, any of her the Mother of Churches Oppo≈øers or Enemies, or contrary to the ≈øame, of which I have here ≈øworn unto: ≈øo God, the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, St. Peter, St. Paul, and the holy Evangeli≈øts help, &c.

body.p: His Highne≈øs Vice Roy of this Nation is of little or no power with the old Natives, therefore your Lord≈øhip will expect of me no more than I am able: This Nation is poor in Wealth, and not ≈øufficient now at pre≈øent to oppo≈øe them: It is ob≈øerved, that ever ≈øince His Highne≈øs's Ance≈øtors had this Nation in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the old Natives have been craving Foreign Powers to A≈ø≈øi≈øt and Rule them; and now both Engli≈øh Race and Iri≈øh begin to oppo≈øe your Lord≈øhips Orders, and do lay a≈øide their National old Quarrels, which I fear will, if any thing will, cau≈øe a Foreigner to invade this Nation: I pray God I may be a fal≈øe Prophet, yet your good Lord≈øhip mu≈øt pardon my opinion, for I write it to your Lord≈øhip as a Warning.
body.closer:
Dublin May 1538
Your humble and true Servant, George Browne, To the Lord Privy Seal with ≈øpeed.

div.p: Upon the Fea≈øt of St. John Bapti≈øt following the ≈øaid Geo ‚Ä¢ ge Browne ≈øeized on one Thady √¥ Brine, one of the Order of ‚Ä¢ t. Francis‚ñ™ who had Papers from Rome, as follows, being ≈øent to the Lord Privy Seal by a Special Me≈ø≈øenger.

body.p:
THou and thy Fathers were all along faithful to the Mother Church of Rome: His Holine≈øs Pau ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, and the Council of the holy Fathers there, have la ‚Ä¢ ely found out a Prophecy, there remaining, of one St. Lac ‚Ä¢ rianus an „Äà‚óä„Äâ Bi≈øhop of Ca≈øhell; wherein he ≈øaith, That the Mother Church of Rome falleth when in Ireland the Catholic faith is ov ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ me: Therefore for the Glory of the Mother Church, the Honour of St. Peter, and your own Securene≈øs, ≈øuppre≈øs Here≈øie and his Holine≈øs's Enemies; for when the Roman Faith there peri≈øheth, the See of Rome falleth al≈øo: therefore the Council of Cardinals have thought fit to encourage your Country of Ireland, (as a ≈øacred I≈øland) being certified, whil≈øt the Mother Church hath a Son of worth as your ≈øelf, and of tho≈øe that ≈øhall ≈øuccour you, and joyn therein, that ≈øhe will never fall, but have more or le≈øs a holding in Britain, in ≈øpite of fate. Thus having obeyed the Order of the mo≈øt ≈øacred Council, we recommend your Princely Per≈øon to the holy Trinity of the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, of St. Peter, St. Paul, and of all the heavenly Ho≈øt of Heaven. Amen.

div.p: Upon further Examinations and ≈øearches made, this Thade √¥ Birue was pillor'd, and confined a pri≈øoner until His Highne≈øs's further Order for his Tryal; but News coming over, that he mu≈øt be Hanged, he made him≈øelf away in the Ca≈øtle of Dublin, on the Eve of the Fea≈øt of St. James; yet his dead Corps was carried to the Gallows Green and hanged up, and after there buried: but it was ≈øaid, by the Regi≈øter of St. Francis Mona≈øtry of Dublin, that they brought him from thence and buried him in that Mona≈øtry.

George Brown having enjoyed the See of Dublin ≈øeven years or thereabouts, King Henry the 8th, upon the Di≈ø≈øolution of the Abbeys, Priorys and Mona≈øtrys here in Ireland, changed the Priory of the Ble≈ø≈øed Trinity of Dublin into a Deanery and Chapters, ≈øince which Mutation, it hath generally bore the Name of Chri≈øt Church.

Upon this Alteration, as it appears upon Record, this Cathedral con≈øi≈øted of a Dean and Chapters, a Chanter, a Trea≈øurer, ≈øix Vicars. Chorals and two Singing Boys, allowing to them two 45 l. 6 s Engli≈øh. (durame bene placito) which Sum his Daughter Queen Mary confirmed for ever, having confirmed the Deanery, yet with Alterations, as ≈øhe was a Romani≈øt.

This Catheral continued after this ≈øaid form (though not in Popery) even until King James his days, who then altered all what King Henry and his Daughter had done, and upon this ≈øecond Alteration he con≈øtituted a Dean, a Chanter, a Chancellor, a Trea≈øurer, three Prebends, ≈øix Vicars, Chorals and four Singing Boys, ordering likewi≈øe that the Archdeacon of Dublin ≈øhould have a Place in the Quire and a Vote in the Chapters. As for a further De≈øcription of this Cathedral, we ≈øhall omit it; having re≈øerved the ≈øame for a large Narrative of the ≈øald Cathedral, in a Book which is ready for the Pre≈øs, entituled, The Amiquities of the City of Dublin.

King Henry the 8th decea≈øing, and his hopeful Offspring King Edward the 6th ≈øucceeding within a ≈øhort ≈øpace after his Royal Fathers Death, that hopeful Prince (by the Advice of his Privy Council) began to con≈øider what good Effects the Tran≈ølation of the holy Bible had done, al≈øo how much it had enlightened the Under≈øtanding of his Subjects, they altered the Liturgy Book from what King Henry had formerly printed and e≈øtabli≈øhed, cau≈øing the ≈øame to be printed in Engli≈øh, commanding the ≈øame to be read and ≈øung in the ≈øeveral Cathedrals and Pari≈øh Churches of England, for the common Benefit of the Nobility, Gentry and Commonalty; and that his Subjects of Ireland might likewi≈øe participate of the ≈øame Sweetne≈øs, he ≈øent over Orders to his Vice Roy Sir Anthony St. Leger then being Lord Deputy of that Nation, that the ≈øame be forthwith there in Ireland ob≈øerved within their ≈øeveral Bi≈øhopricks, Cathedrals and Pari≈øh Churches; which was fir≈øt ob≈øerved in Christ Church at Dublin, on the Fea≈øt of Ea≈øter 1551. before the ≈øaid Sir Antbony, George Browne, and the Mayor and Bayliffs of Dublin, John Lockwood being then Dean of the ≈øaid Cathedral.

div.head: The Tran≈ølation of the Copy of the Order for the Liturgy of the Church of England to be read in Ireland runs as follows.

opener.signed: EDWARD by the Grace of God, &c.

div.p: Whereas our Gratious Father, King Henry the 8th of happy memory, taking into con≈øideration the Bondage and heavy Yoak that his true and faithful Subjects ≈øu≈øtained under the Iuri≈ødiction of the Bi≈øhop of Rome, as al≈øo the Ignorance the Commonalty were in, how ≈øeveral fabulous Stories and lying Wonders mi≈ø≈øed our Subjects in both our Realms of England and Ireland, gra≈øping thereby the means thereof into their hands, al≈øo di≈øpen≈øing with the Sins of our Nations by their Indulgen≈øes and Pardons for Gain, purpo≈øely to cheri≈øh all evil Vices, as Robberies, Rebellions, Thefts, Whoredoms, Bla≈øphemy, Idolatry, &c. He, our Grations Father King Henry of happy memory, hereupon di≈ø≈øolbed all Priors, Mona≈øtrys, Abbeys, and other pretended Religious Hou≈øes, as being but Nur≈øeries for Vice or Luxury, more than for ≈øacred Learning; He therefore, that it might more plainly appear to the World, that tho≈øe Orders had kept the light of the Go≈øpel from his People, he thought it mo≈øt fit and convenient for the Pre≈øervation of their Souls and Bodies, that the holy Scriptures ≈øhould be Tran≈ølated, Printed and placed in all Pari≈øh Churches within his Dominions, for his faithful Subjects to encrea≈øe their knowledg of God and of our Saviour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. We therefore, for the general Benefit of our well-beloved Subjects Vnder≈øtandings, when ever a≈ø≈øembled or met together in the ≈øaid ≈øeveral Pari≈øh Churches, either to pray or to hear Prayers read, that they may the better joyn therein, in Vnity, Hearts and Voice, have cau≈øed the Liturgy and Prayers of the Church to be tran≈ølated into our Mother Tongue of this Realm of England according to the A≈ø≈øembly of Divines lately met within the ≈øame for that purpo≈øe. We therefore Will and Command, as al≈øo Authorize you Sir Anthony S. Leger knight, our Vice-Roy of that our kingdom of Ireland, to give ≈øpecial notice to all our Clergy, as well Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Deans, Archdeacons, as others our Secular Pari≈øh Prie≈øts within that our ≈øaid Kingdom of Ireland, to perfect, execute and obey this our Royal Will and Plea≈øure accordingly.
div.closer:
Given at our Mannor of Greenwich, Febr. 6. in the Fifth year of our Reign.
E. R. To our tru≈øty and well-beloved Sir. Anth. St. Leger Knight our Chief Governour of our Kingdom of Ireland.

div.head: Several Collections from Anthony Martin, formerly Bi≈øhop of Meath
div.p: BEfore Proclamations were i≈ø≈øued out, Sir Anthony St. Leger, upon this Order, called an A≈ø≈øembly of the Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, together with other of the then Clergy of Ireland, in which A≈ø≈øembly he ≈øignified unto them as well His Maje≈øties Order afore≈øaid, as al≈øo the Opinions of tho≈øe Bi≈øhops and Clergy of England, who had adhered unto the Order, ≈øaying that it was his Maje≈øties Will and Plea≈øure, confenting unto their ≈øerious Con≈øiderations and Opinions, then acted and agreed on in England as to Eccle≈øia≈øtical matters, that the ≈øame be in Ireland ≈øo likewi≈øe celebrated and performed.

Sir Anthony St. Leger having ≈øpoken to this effect, George dowdall, who ≈øucceeded George Cromer in the Primacy of Armagh, ≈øtood up, who (through his Romi≈øh Zeal to the Pope) laboured with all his power and force to oppo≈øe the Liturgyof the Church, that it might not be read or ≈øung in the Church; ≈øaying, then ≈øhall every illiterate fellow read Service (or Ma≈øs) as he in tho≈øe days termed the word Service.

To this Saying of the Archbi≈øhops, Sir Anthony replyed, No, your Grace is mi≈øtaken, for we have too many illiterate Prie≈øts among≈øt us already, who neither can pronounce the Latine, nor know what it means, no more than the Common people that hear them; but when the people hear the Liturgy in Engli≈øh, they and the Prie≈øt will then under≈øtand what they pray for.
Upon this Reply, George dowdall bade Sir Anthony beware of the Clergles Cur≈øe.
Sir Anthony made an≈øwer, I fear no ≈øtrange Cur≈øe, ≈øo long as I have the Ble≈ø≈øing of that Church which I believe to be the true one.
The Archbi≈øhop again ≈øaid, can there be a truer Church than the Church of Saint Peter, the Mother Church of Rome.
Sir Anthony returned this an≈øwer, I thought we had bin all of the Church of Chri≈øt; for he calls all true believers in him his Church, and him≈øelf the Head thereof.
The Archbi≈øhop replied‚ñ™ and is not St. Peter the Church of Chri≈øt?
Sir Anthony returned this An≈øwer, St. Peter was a Member of Chri≈øts Church, but the Church was not St. Peters, neither was St. Peter but Chri≈øe the Head thereof.

Then George Dowdall the Primate of Armagh ro≈øe up, and ≈øeveral of the Suftragan Bi≈øhops under his Juri≈ødiction, ≈øaving only Edward Staples then Bi≈øhop of Meath, who tarried with the re≈øt of the Clergy then a≈ø≈øembled, on the Kalends of March according to the old ≈øtile, 1551. but if we rea≈øon as from the Annunication of our Lady, which was the 25th of March, it was 1550.

Sir Anthony then took up the Order, and held it forth to George Browns Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, who (≈øtanding up) received it, ≈øaying; this Order, good Brethren, is from our Gracious King, and from the re≈øt of our Brethren, the Fathers and Clergy of England, who have con≈øulted herein, and
compared the holy Scriptures with what they have done; unto whom I ≈øubmit, as Je≈øus did to Cae≈øar, in all things ju≈øt and lawful, making no que≈øtion why or wherefore, as We own Him our true and lawfull King.

After this ≈øeveral of the meeker or mo≈øt moderate of the Bi≈øhops and Clergy of Ireland cohered with George Browne the Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, among≈øt whom Edward Staples Bi≈øhop of Meath, who was put out from his Bi≈øhoprick, for ≈øo doing, in Queen Mary's days on the 29th of June 1554. John Bale, who on the ≈øecond of February 1552. was Con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of O≈ø≈øory for his fidelity, and afterwards by Queen Mary expul≈øed. Al≈øo Thomas Lanca≈øter Bi≈øhop of Kildare, who was at the ≈øame tim ‚Ä¢ put from his Bi≈øhoprick, with ≈øeveral others of the Clergy, being all expul≈øed upon Queen Maries coming to the Crown.

When the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages had pa≈ø≈øed: Sir Anthony was in a ≈øhort time after recalled for England, and Sir James Crofts of Hereford≈øhire Knight, placed Chief in his ≈øtead; who began his Government from the 29th of April, 1551.

Sir James Crofts upon his coming over endeavoured much for the per≈øwading of George Dowdall to adhere to the Order a≈øore≈øaid; but Dowdall being ob≈øtinate, his Maje≈øty and the Learned Privy Council then of England, (for his perver≈øne≈øs) upon the 20th. of October following took away the Title of Primate of all Ireland from him, and conferred the ≈øame on George Browne then Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, and to his Succe≈ø≈øors, by rea≈øon that he was the fir≈øt of the Iri≈øh Bi≈øhops who embraced the Order for E≈øtabli≈øhing of the Engli≈øh Liturgy and Reformation in Ireland; which place he enjoyed during the remainder of King Edwards's Reign, and for a certain time after; as you ≈øhall know further in its due cour≈øe and place.

Alterations following one after another, (even upon this Reformation of the Church of England) and the Title of Primacy being di≈øpo≈øed of, as we have already mentioned‚ñ™ unto George Brown afore≈øaid; ≈øome Writers ≈øaying that George dowdall was bani≈øhed, others that he was not, but went voluntary of his own will; yet, not to di≈øpute the ca≈øe, another Archbi≈øhop was con≈øecrated in lieu of him, though then living; by which it was then held lawful; as al≈øo that con≈øtituting of Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops was in the power of Kings, and not in the power of Popes, or of the Bi≈øhop of Rome, which would be much to the Aba≈øement of the Powers of the Crown of England ever to re≈øign, or to acknowledge to the contrary.

Hugh Goodacre Bachelour of Divinity was con≈øecrated Archbi≈øhop of Armagh by the ≈øaid George Browne, together with John Bale Bi≈øhop of O≈ø≈øory, (already mentioned) in Chri≈øt Church in Dublin, on the ≈øecond of February, Anno 1552. Thomas Bi≈øhop of Kildare and Tugenius Bi≈øhop of Down- and Connon a≈ø≈øi≈øting him; yet notwith≈øtanding Hugh Goodacre's Con≈øecration‚ñ™ George Browne then held the Title of Primacy of all Ireland.

This Reformation and Alteration having not time to ≈øettle, or to take root, it was ≈øoon qua≈øhed and pulled down, by that lamentable lo≈øs of that hopeful Prince King Edward the Sixth, who died at Greenwich the 6th of June‚ñ™ 1553.

Upon King Edward's Decea≈øe, the Council having met to con≈øult together upon the Affairs of the≈øe Dominions, as al≈øo how they might confirm and e≈øtabli≈øh what they had already ordered and enacted, as well in Eccl≈øiea≈øtical matters as Temporal, a Divi≈øion ≈øoon ≈øprung up, ≈øome being for the Choice of the Lady Jane Gray, others for Queen Mary, at la≈øt upon conclu≈øion Mary the Kings Si≈øter was voted Queen, upon the Propo≈øals and Promi≈øes which ≈øhe made to the Council, to confirm all that had been perfected by her Father King Henry the 8th. and her Brother King Edward and his Honoured Council.

After ≈øhe had been crowned and enthroned, ≈øhe, for the ≈øpace of three or four months, ≈øeemed moderate to the Prote≈øtant Reformers, yet all that while combining with Rome and her Emi≈ø≈øaries; but having accompli≈øhed her De≈øigns, ≈øhe revoked her fair Promi≈øes, (which with Papi≈øts is a Rule) e≈øteeming it no ≈øin to break Contracts or Covenants with Hereticks and Prote≈øtants, numbred with ≈øuch ≈øort of People, e≈øpecially with Papi≈øts, the≈øe promi≈øes vani≈øhed; and then began the Romi≈øh Church not only to undo what King Henry and his Son King Edward had reformed, but to pro≈øecute the Reformers and Reformed with Fire and Faggot.

But to our purpo≈øe, upon the 11th of November Anno 1553. ≈øhe recalled Sir James Crofts, and ≈øent over Sir Anthony St. Leger Lord Deputy into Ireland. This Sir Anthony had not been half a year Chief Governour of Ireland, before Queen Mary revoked the Title of Primacy from George Browne, expul≈øing Hugh Goodacre out of the Archbi≈øhopric of Armagh, and recalling George Dowdall to his See, and re≈øtoring him to the Primacy of all Ireland, as formerly, which Title hath ever ≈øince ≈øtood firm in Armagh, without any Revocation, either by Queen Elizabeth, or by any of her Succe≈ø≈øors.

George Browne, upon this Revocation, was by George Dowdall expul≈øed, and not thought fit to continue in his See of Dublin, as being a married man, and it is thought, had he not been married he had been expul≈øed, having appeared ≈øo much for the Reformation‚ñ™ in both the≈øe former Kings days, upon the expul≈øing of this George Browne, all the Temporalities belonging to the Archbi≈øhoprick were di≈øpo≈øed of unto Thomas Lockwood then Dean of Chri≈øt Church in Dublin. It having been an antient Cu≈øtom ever upon the Tran≈ølation or Death of any of tho≈øe Archbi≈øhops, to depo≈øite the Temporalities into the hands of the Priors formerly of that Cathedral when it was a Priory, and called by the name of the Cathedral of the Ble≈ø≈øed Trinity And it is ob≈øervable, the la≈øt Prior became the fir≈øt Dean upon the alteration as afore≈øaid.

The See of Dublin after this Expul≈øion lay vacant for two years or thereabouts, until Hugh Corrin alias Corwine was placed therein: This Hugh was borne in We≈øtmoreland, a Doctor of the Law, being formerly Archdeacon of Oxford and Dean of Hereford, he was con≈øecrated Archbi≈øhop of Dublin in the Cathedral of St. Pauls in London on the 8th of September, Anno 1555. He after, upon the 13th of the ≈øame Month, was by Queen Mary made Chancellor of Ireland, and upon the 25th of the ≈øaid September, he received this Letter from the Queen, directed to Thomas Lockwood the Dean of Chri≈øt-Church, it being an antient cu≈øtome formerly to recommend the Archbi≈øhop, when≈øoever con≈øtituted for that See, to the Prior of that ≈øaid Cathedral.

body.head: Queen Maries Letter to the Dean and Chapter of Chri≈øt Church in Dublin, to receive the Archbi≈øhop of Dublin honourably, and with due re≈øpect. Copia vera, ex Libro nigro Sanctae Trinitatis Dublinii.
body.p: TRu≈øty and wellbeloved, We greet you well; and for a≈ømuch as the Right Reverend Father in God, our Right tru≈øty and wellbeloved Coun≈øellor the Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, being lately cho≈øen for that See, reparieth ≈øpeedily to that our Realm of Ireland, as well to re≈øide upon the Cure of his Bi≈øhoprick, which now of long time hath been de≈øtitute of a Catholick Bi≈øhop, as al≈øo to occupy the Office of our high Chancellor of that our Realm; albeit we have good hopes ye will in all things of your ≈øelves carry your ≈øelves towards him as becometh you, yet to the intent he might the better govern the Charge committed unto him, to the Honour of Almighty God, and for the remain of our Service We have thought fit to require and charge you, that for your part ye do reverently receive him, honour and humbly obey him in all things, as appertaineth to your Duties tending to Gods glory, our Honour, and the Common-weal of that our Realm; whereby ye ≈øhall plea≈øe God and do us acceptable Service.

closer.dateline: Given under our Signet at our Mannor of Greenwich, the 25th of September, in the ≈øecond and third years of our Reign.

body.trailer: To our tru≈øty and well beloved the Dean and Chapter of the Cathedral of Chri≈øt Church within our Realm of Ireland.

div.p: I have here in≈øerted this Letter, upon two accounts, fir≈øt as being a Record remaining in the Cathedral; ≈øecondly, becau≈øe there hath been ≈øome di≈øcour≈øe of late, whether the Archbi≈øhop of Dublin had power herein, or whether it was upon King Henrys Mutation made a Deanery as Whitehall Chappel is, and no Cathedral; but by this Letter it ≈øhews it is both ≈øtill a Cathedral, and ≈øubject to the Archbi≈øhop of Dublin.

George Browne lived not long after the Con≈øecration of this Hugh Corwine, yet I have among my Manu≈øcripts a Writting of a Papi≈øt, who would fain have per≈øwaded the world that this George Browne dyed through Joy, having had a Bull from the Pope to be re≈øtored to his See of Dublin, which mu≈øt needs be fal≈øe, upon this account of Sir James Wares, who writeth the≈øe very words of him, in his Book entituled De Prae≈øulibus Hiberniae‚ñ™ pag. 120. 1554. Circa tempus Georgius Browneys (quod conjugatus e≈ø≈øet) per Dowdallu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Archiepi≈øcopum Armachanum & alios Delegatos ex Authoritatus e≈øt; otherwi≈øe the Pope, if he had granted ≈øuch a Bull, mu≈øt likewi≈øe have di≈øpen≈øed with his Marriage, it being contrary to the Romi≈øh Tenents for Bi≈øhops to marry.
Having related thus much of George Browne, and of Eccle≈øia≈øtical matters during his life, we ≈øhall proceed a little further concerning a ≈øhort Sermon of his, preached unto the people in Chri≈øt Church, upon the fir≈øt Sunday after Ea≈øter, anno 1551. being a Copy of the ≈øame given to Sir James Ware Knight, by Anthony Martin late Bi≈øhop of Meath, who formerly was Tutor to the ≈øaid Sir James Ware, when he was a Student in Trinity Colledge Dublin.

epigraph.q: Open mine eyes, that I may ≈øee the wonders of thy Law.

div.p: THe wonders of the Lord God have for a long time been hid from the children of Men, which hath hapned by Rome's not permitting the common people to read the holy Scriptures; for to prevent you, that you might not know the comfort of your Salvation, but to depend wholly on the Church of Rome, they will not permit it to be in any tongue but in the Latin, ≈øaying that Latin was the Roman Tongue: But the wonderful God in≈øpired the holy Apo≈øtles with the knowledge of all Languages, that they might teach all people in their proper Tongue and Language, which cau≈øed our wi≈øe King Henry, before his death, to have the holy Scriptures tran≈øcribed into the Engli≈øh Tongue, for the good of his Subjects, that their eyes may be opened to behold the wondrous things out of the Law of the Lord. But there are fal≈øe Prophets at this in≈øtant, and will be to the end of the World, that ≈øhall deceive you with fal≈øe Doctrines, expounding this Text, or that, purpo≈øely to confound your under≈øtandings, and to lead you captive into a wilderne≈øs of Confu≈øion, whom you ≈øhall take as your friends, but they ≈øhall be your greate≈øt enemies, ≈øpeaking again≈øt the Tenents of Rome and yet be ≈øet on by Rome; the≈øe ≈øhall be a rigid people full of fury and envy.

But to prevent the≈øe things that are to come, ob≈øerve Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles; Let all things be done with with decency, with mildne≈øs, and in order, ≈øervently crying
unto God, Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold the wondrous things out of thy Law, then ≈øhould you rightly keep the Law and the Prophets. It is the part of a Prince to be wi≈øe, for he hath a great Charge to Rule and govern a Nation: Your late King fore≈øeeing Rome and her Pope's intentions, how that he intended to in≈ølave his Subjects, and to keep them in the ≈øtate of ignorance, con≈øulted with the Learned of his Realm, knowing that Youth might quickly be wrought on, therefore he prepared before his death a wi≈øe and Learned ≈øort of Coun≈øellors for his Sons Over≈øeers, not tru≈øting to one or two, but to ≈øeveral, that he might the better Rule his people, who≈øe eyes the Lord God Almighty hath opened betimes, to behold his wondrous works.

Though the words of my Text be plainly thus (Open thou mine eyes) the meane≈øt of you that hear me have eyes, but the true meaning of the words is, Endue us with under≈øtanding; for a Fool hath eyes, and ≈øees men, women, bea≈øts, birds, and other things, but yet wants under≈øtanding: So when we ≈øay, Open thou our eyes, we de≈øire the Lord God to in≈øtruct and teach us the knowledge of his Laws.

When you were lately led in blindne≈øs, your eyes beheld the Images that then ≈øtood in ≈øeveral of the Mona≈øteries and Churches until they were removed; yet all this while were your under≈øtandings blinded, becau≈øe ye believed in them, and placed your tru≈øt in them.

Suppo≈øe an Arti≈øt or Workman make an Image either of Man or Woman, and at la≈øt a Clergy man of Rome give it ≈øuch a name, calling it St. Peter, or St. Paul, or St. Mary, or St. Anne; mu≈øt not that man, though he behold his own handy work, and knows in his heart that it was his own work, blind, and void of
and under≈øtanding of the Law of God, and of the wondrous things that are contained in the Law of the Lord; Yes ≈øurely, he mu≈øt be blind, and void of Rea≈øon, and of the true Faith, that would wor≈øhip the ≈øame.

The Workman carved the Eyes, but the≈øe Eyes ≈øee not; he likewi≈øe carved the Ears, but they hear not; the No≈øe, and it ≈ømells not; the Mouth, and it neither breaths nor ≈øpeaks; the Hands, they feel not; the Feet, but they ≈øtand ≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ k ≈øtill.

How therefore can your prayers be acceptable unto this Image, that ≈øees you not approaching towards it, that hears you not when you pray to it, that ≈ømells not the ≈øweet ≈ømells, be they of Myrrhe or Frankincen≈øe burning before it? How can it ab≈øolve you, when the mouth is not able to ≈øay, Thy ≈øins are forgiven thee‚ñ™ And if you place a certain ≈øum of Money in the palm of the hand of that Image; come you again to morrow, the Money, it is true ≈øhall find a cu≈øtomer, but the Image never the wi≈øer who took it; and if you de≈øire to have it come unto you it cannot without help; therefore the Workman that made this Image, is as blind, as deaf, as dumb, and as void of ≈øen≈øe as the Image it ≈øelf, and ≈øo be ye all that put your tru≈øt in them.

Therefore of late new Artificers, by ≈øprings have made artificial ones, which for a certain time ≈øhall move, and ye ≈øhall believe it to be real and certain: But beware good people, for they be but lying wonders, purpo≈øely that ye may break the Law of God. And thus hath the Devil devi≈øed a lying wonder, that ye may be deluded to break the Law of the Lord, which is, Thou ≈øhalt not make unto thy ≈øelf any Graven Image. O Lord, open thou our Eyes, our Ears, and our Under≈øtanding, that we may behold the wondrous things that are in thy Law. The Law of God is an undefiled Law. Oh! why ≈øhould we be ≈øo wicked then as to defile that Law, which the
Almighty God hath made ≈øo pure without blemi≈øh. Je≈øus came to fulfil the Law, and not to aboli≈øh the Law. But there are a new fraternity of late ≈øprung up, who call them≈øelves Je≈øuits, which will deceive many, who are much after the Scribes and Phari≈øees manner: Among≈øt the Jews they ≈øhall ≈øtrive to aboli≈øh the truth, and ≈øhall come very near to do it; for the≈øe ≈øorts will turn them≈øelves into ≈øeveral forms, with the Heathen, an Heatheni≈øt; with Athei≈øts, an Athei≈øt; with the Jews, a Jew; and with the Reformers, a Refomade, purpo≈øely to know your intenations, your minds, your hearts, and your inclintions, and thereby bring you at la≈øt to be like the fool that ≈øaid in his heart there was no God. The≈øe ≈øhall ≈øpread over the whole World, ≈øhall be admitted into the Council of Princes, and they never the wi≈øer; Charming of them, yea, making your Princes reveal their hearts, and the ≈øecrets therein unto them, and yet they not perceive it; which will happen from falling from the Law of God, by neglect of fulfilling of the Law of God, and by winking at their ≈øins; yet in the end, God to ju≈øtifie his Law, ≈øhall ≈øuddenly cut off this Society even by the hands of tho≈øe who have mo≈øt ≈øuccour'd them, and made u≈øe of them; ≈øo that at the end they ≈øhall become odious to all Nations: They ≈øhall be wor≈øe than Jews, having no re≈øting place upon the Earth, and then ≈øhall a Jew have more favour than a Je≈øuite. Now, to arm you all good Chri≈øtians again≈øt the≈øe things that are to come, le≈øt ye be led into temptation; Cry unto the Lord your God, and heartily pray that he would be ≈øo merciful unto you as to open the eyes of your under≈øtanding, that you may behold the wonders and plea≈øantne≈øs that is in his Law. Which God of his mercy grant that you may all do.

Thus concluding with the Acts and Deeds of this Reverend Father, we ≈øhall end with Queen Maries De≈øigns, how ≈øhe intended to have per≈øecuted the Prote≈øtants in Ireland; but by Providence prevented; as you ≈øhall further know by this following Relation being averred by ≈øeveral ≈øufficient per≈øons, as well Eccle≈øia≈øtical as Civil.

Qu. Mary having dealt ≈øeverely with the Prote≈øtants in England, about the latter end of her Reign, ≈øigned a Commi≈ø≈øion fo ‚Ä¢ to take the ≈øame cour≈øe with them in Ireland, and to execut ‚Ä¢ the ≈øame with greater force, ≈øhe nominates Doctor Cole one of the Commi≈ø≈øioners, ≈øending the Commi≈ø≈øion by this Doctor, who in his Journey coming to Che≈øter, the Mayor of that City hearing that Her Maje≈øty was ≈øending a Me≈ø≈øenger into Ireland, and he being a Churchman waited on the Doctor, who in di≈øcour≈øe with the Mayor taketh out of a Cloak-bag a Leather Box, ≈øaying unto him, Here is a Commi≈ø≈øion that ≈øhall la≈øh the Hereticks of Ireland, calling the Prote≈øtants by that title; The good Woman of the Hou≈øe being well affected to the Prote≈øtant Religion, and al≈øo having a Brother named John Edmonds of the ≈øame, then a Citizen in Dublin, was much troubled at the Doctors words; but watching her convenient time, whil≈øt the Mayor took his leave, and the Doctor complementing him down the ≈øtairs, ≈øhe opens the Box and takes the Commi≈ø≈øion out, placing in lieu thereof a Sheet of paper with a Pack of Cards, the Knave of Clubs faced uppermo≈øt, wrapt up. The Doctor coming up to his Chamber, ≈øu≈øpecting nothing of what had been done, put up the Box as formerly. The next day, going to the Water≈øide, wind and Weather ≈øerving him, he ≈øails towards Ireland, and landed on the Seventh of October, 1558. at Dublin; then coming to the Ca≈øtle, the Lord Fitz Walters being Lord Deputy ≈øent for him to come before him and the Privy Council, who coming in, after he had made a Speech relating upon what account he came over, he pre≈øents the Box unto the Lord Deputv, who cau≈øing it to be opened, that the Secretary might read the Commi≈ø≈øion, there was nothing ≈øave a pack of Cards with the Knave of Clubs uppermo≈øt, which not only ≈øtartled the Lord Deputy and Council, but the Doctor, who a≈ø≈øured them he had a Commi≈ø≈øion, but knew not how it was gone; then the Lord Deputy made an≈øwer, Let us have another Commi≈ø≈øion, and we will ≈øhuffle the Cards in the mean
while: The Doctor being troubled in his mind went away‚ñ™ and returned into England; and coming to the Court obtained another Commi≈ø≈øion; but ≈øtaying for a wind at the water≈øide, news came unto him, that the Queen was dead, and thus God pre≈øerved the Prote≈øtants in Ireland.
